results.title: Accounting
results.brief_description: This program looks at what attracts people to Accounting as a career. It also looks at how computerization has changed the face of accounting. Industry and commerce, Government agencies, public accounting, education (research and development) are all possible career areas which require accountants.

results.title: Accountancy today!
results.brief_description: A career film. An Accountant needs an inquiring mind and the ability to communicate effectively; he must collect and record facts, analyse them, prepare reports, discuss financial implications, control their results. After a three year full-time course of study at a university or technical college, he can gain employment in a secure, well-paid position which may lead to promotion to top executive positions in commerce, industry, government departments or private practice.

results.title: According to specification?
results.creator_credit: Technical and Scientific Films, British Productivity Council, Denis Ward and Phil Dennis
results.brief_description: The problem of maintaining a consistent quality standard in manufactured products is discussed by a Production Director and a Sales Director. Conventional methods of inspection between processes and again of the final product prove too costly, and it is decided that quality control should become part of the manufacturing process. The practical, theoretical and statistical aspects of quality control are fully developed.

results.title: Accomplished women
results.creator_credit: Films Incorporated, Charles Braverman and Jerry Kramer
results.brief_description: Six women, including Helen Reddy, who have made it to the top in their chosen fields discuss a wide range of topics from politics to personal feelings. Highlights changing attitudes of women about themselves. The other women include Shirley Chisholm (Member of the US Congress), La Donna Harris (Founder - Americans for Indian Opportunity), Katherine Graham (Business woman - Washington Post), Nikki Giovanni (Poet), Virginia Apgar (Pediatrics specialist).

results.title: Accidents will happen
results.creator_credit: Cinemedia, XYZ, Fabienne Nicholas and Guy Richards
results.brief_description: In an attempt to pay his son’s medical bills following an unfortunate accident, a father (Brett Swain) sends in handicam footage of Timmy’s mishap into the reality show, “Accidents will happen”. His wife (Anni Finsterer) is bitterly disappointed, but makes the journey into the studio with the family when they are in contention for a financial benefit. When the production crew discover the faux accident has resulted in Timmy becoming wheelchair bound, they send down an executive (Chris Haywood) to reneg the claim and all appears to be lost. A timely tale about reality television that featured as part of the St Kilda Film Festival and Touring Film Festival, 1999. Cast also includes Michael Barrallon, Emily Barr, Alan Dale and Tania Lacy.

results.title: Accidents don't happen. Ch. 5: safe clothing
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Donald Mulholland and David Bairstow
results.brief_description: Brogan thinks Foreman McCardle has gone clean off his rocker when he has him, Brogan, carted away to the clinic although he’s perfectly well. When Nurse Gilfillan starts to operate - on Brogan’s trailing necktie, baggy-sleeved sweater, cuffed pants and worn-out shoes - horrid tales of workers who had worn similar clothing and been reduced to near-hamburger make everything quite clear. Cast: Joseph Carr, Marcia Diamond, Alfie Scopp

results.title: Accidents don't happen. Ch. 4: falls
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Fred Lasse and Donald Mulholland
results.brief_description: Spotlights the most common causes of serious falls in industry. While an ironic commentary suggests new and better ways of tripping people up, we see workers drop truck handles in the aisles, neglect loose floor boards, leave pails on stairs, climb on rickety boxes, and use an extension ladder without safety feet. The film ends with practical advice on how to eliminate factory danger spots that may result in bad falls.
